title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #702: Singleton Intersections**

For k ≥ 4, if a k-uniform family F has more than C(n-2, k-2) sets, must it contain A, B with |A ∩ B| = 1?

**Answer: YES** (Frankl 1977)

The bound is tight: all k-sets through two fixed points avoid singleton intersections.

title: IsKUniform
content:
**k-Uniform Family:** All sets in F have exactly k elements.

This is the standard uniformity condition in extremal set theory.

title: SingletonIntersection
content:
**Singleton Intersection:** Two sets A, B with |A ∩ B| = 1.

They share exactly one element. The problem asks when such pairs must exist.

title: AvoidsSingletonIntersections
content:
**Avoids Singleton Intersections:** No two distinct sets share exactly one element.

The extremal family achieves this by making all sets share at least 2 elements.

title: HasSingletonPair
content:
**Has Singleton Pair:** There exist A, B ∈ F with A ≠ B and |A ∩ B| = 1.

Frankl's theorem says this occurs when |F| > C(n-2, k-2).

title: extremal_construction
content:
**Extremal Construction:** Fix two elements x, y. Take all k-sets containing both.

This family has C(n-2, k-2) sets and avoids singleton intersections: any two sets share at least {x, y}.

title: Why C(n-2, k-2)
content:
**Why This Bound?** Choosing k-2 elements from {1,...,n}\{x,y} gives C(n-2, k-2) sets.

Each set contains {x,y} plus k-2 other elements.

title: frankl_theorem
content:
**Frankl's Theorem (1977):** For k ≥ 4, if |F| > C(n-2, k-2), then F has a singleton pair.

This confirms the Erdős-Sós conjecture and shows the bound is tight.

title: katona_k4
content:
**Katona's Case k=4 (unpublished):** The first case, proved before Frankl's general result.

For 4-subsets of {1,...,n} with |F| > C(n-2, 2), a singleton pair exists.

title: k3_fails
content:
**k=3 Fails:** The condition k ≥ 4 is necessary.

For k=3, there exist large 3-uniform families exceeding C(n-2, 1) that still avoid singleton intersections.

title: erdos_702
content:
**Erdős Problem #702: SOLVED**

Main theorem: For k ≥ 4 and |F| > C(n-2, k-2), the family F contains a singleton intersection pair.

**Key:** Proved by Frankl (1977), earlier by Katona for k=4.
